channel.title: Blogs on SQL at Scale
channel.description: Recent content in Blogs on SQL at Scale

item.title: Gaining 3x Throughput by Migrating from Aurora to a Scale-Out MySQL Alternative
item.description: PayPay is Japan's largest mobile payment company. Learn how they achieved 3x throughput by migrating from Aurora to TiDB, a scale-out MySQL alternative.

item.title: TiDB on KubeSphere: Release a Cloud-Native Distributed Database to the KubeSphere App Store
item.description: This article walks you through how to deploy TiDB on KubeSphere and release TiDB to the App Store to make it available to other tenants.

item.title: Tips and Tricks for Writing Linux BPF Applications with libbpf
item.description: Compared to BCC, the libbpf + BPF CO-RE solution greatly reduces storage space and runtime overhead. That's why we switched from bcc-tools to libbpf-tools. This post introduces some tips and tricks for writing BPF applications with libbpf.

item.title: Why We Disable Linux's THP Feature for Databases
item.description: This post dives deep into how transparent huge pages (THP) slow down the system and explains why you should disable THP to improve your database performance.

item.title: How China's Insurance Giant Improved Agile Application Performance with a NewSQL Database
item.description: Ping An Life Insurance shares a case where TiDB helped them support 100 billion RMB payment volume in a single day, the pain points before they used TiDB, how they use TiDB, and why they chose TiDB.

item.title: Why We Switched from BCC to libbpf for Linux BPF Performance Analysis
item.description: Libbpf + BPF CO-RE is better than BCC. It greatly reduces storage space and runtime overhead, and it improves programmers’ deployment and development experience.

item.title: How We Reduced Our Batch Processing Time by About 58% with a Scale-Out MySQL Alternative
item.description: WeBank is China's first privately-owned Internet bank. As they grew, they encountered database performance and capacity bottlenecks. By using TiDB, a scale-out MySQL alternative, they reduced their batch processing time by ~58%.

item.title: How a Top Game Company Uses Chaos Engineering to Improve Testing
item.description: NetEase Fuxi AI Lab is China's first professional game AI research institution. In their search for a Chaos Engineering tool to test their Kubernetes-based AI training platform, they chose Chaos Mesh and have improved their system resiliency ever since.

item.title: Best Practices for TiDB on AWS Cloud
item.description: This article illustrates the best practices of running TiDB on AWS, including how to choose the suitable cloud storage and properly configure the system.

item.title: How We Process Data Five Times More Efficiently Using a Scale-Out MySQL Alternative
item.description: A senior architect at China Telecom Bestpay shared how TiDB, a MySQL-compatible, distributed SQL database, boosted the performance of their core systems by 3–5 times.

item.title: PingCAP, the Company Behind TiDB, Raises $270 Million in Series D Funding
item.description: With great pleasure, we are announcing that we have raised $270 million in Series D funding led by global investors. We are looking for more innovations, global expansion, and more team growth as we strive to build the database of the future.

item.title: TiDB on KubeSphere: Run a Cloud-Native Distributed Database on a Hybrid-Cloud Kubernetes Platform
item.description: A site reliability engineer gives a step-by-step tutorial on how to deploy TiDB on KubeSphere, an open-source, distributed GUI operating system with Kubernetes as its kernel.

item.title: Embracing NewSQL: Why We Chose TiDB over MongoDB and MySQL
item.description: In this post, PalFish explains why they chose TiDB over MongoDB and MySQL. The key factors were their application requirements and their perspective on NewSQL databases.

item.title: Flink + TiDB: A Scale-Out Real-Time Data Warehouse for Second-Level Analytics
item.description: By combining Apache Flink and TiDB, we offer an efficient, easy-to-use, real-time data warehouse with horizontal scalability and high availability.

item.title: DM 2.0 GA: Secure, Easy, Highly Available Data Migration
item.description: DM 2.0 has reached general availability. It supports highly available migration tasks and shard merging and migration in optimistic mode.

item.title: Choosing the Right Enterprise-Grade Disaster Recovery Solution for the Financial Industry
item.description: Financial companies have stringent requirements for high availability and disaster recovery, which many databases cannot meet. This article describes how TiDB addresses both these issues with a range of options that make it an excellent choice for the industry.

item.title: Metrics Relation Graph Helps DBAs Quickly Locate Performance Problems in TiDB
item.description: TiDB v4.0.7 introduced a new feature: the metrics relation graph. It helps users clearly see the relationship between different performance metrics in a database cluster and thus quickly locate the root causes of performance problems.

item.title: Running a Scale-Out Database on ARM as a MySQL Alternative
item.description: In this article, an engineer at U-Next talks about why they chose TiDB and why they run it on the ARM architecture. He also provides detailed benchmarking results showing that TiDB runs equally well on ARM and x86.

item.title: Making an HTAP Database a Reality: What I Learned from PingCAP's VLDB Paper
item.description: Recently, VLDB published the PingCAP paper, TiDB: A Raft-based HTAP Database. In this article, a DBA at PalFish shares his thoughts on the article and his expectations for TiDB's future development.

item.title: A 3x IT Efficiency Boost: Using a Scale-Out HTAP Database for Near Real-Time Analytics
item.description: As its business quickly grew, ZTO Express found Exadata, Kudu, and HBase couldn't meet their database requirements. To scale out their database and perform multi-dimensional analytics in near real time, they migrated from Oracle Exadata to TiDB.

item.title: TiCDC GA: Offering High-Availability Replication Services for Production Environments
item.description: TiCDC is TiDB's change data capture framework. It is now generally available. This post introduces its features, application scenarios, and real-world case studies.

item.title: TiDB X Hacktoberfest 2020 - An Invitation to Open Source
item.description: TiDB is in Hacktoberfest, a celebration open to everyone in our global community. Whether you're an experienced developer or an open-source newbie learning to code, you can help drive the growth of open source and make positive contributions to the ever-growing TiDB community.

item.title: How Bank of China Uses a Scale-Out Database to Support Zabbix Monitoring at Scale
item.description: To monitor their large-scale IT infrastructure, Bank of China chose TiDB, a scale-out relational database, to replace Zabbix's MySQL backend. Learn how they use TiDB to manage over 10,000 monitored devices and 18 TB data.

item.title: How We Use a Distributed Database to Achieve Horizontal Scaling Without Downtime
item.description: Bank of Beijing sought an open-source, horizontally scalable database to scale out their database. Learn how they use TiDB to achieve database scaling with zero downtime.

item.title: Lessons from TiDB's No. 1 Bug Hunters Who've Found 400+ Bugs in Popular DBMSs
item.description: Dr. Manuel Rigger and his colleague have found 400+ bugs in popular DBMSs, including 50+ TiDB bugs. Learn their experience in finding logic bugs in DBMSs.

item.title: How We Use a Scale-Out HTAP Database for Real-Time Analytics and Complex Queries
item.description: Xiaohongshu receives more than 100 million rows of data every day. They adopted TiDB because it supports both transactional and analytical queries, real-time data analytics, and horizontal scalability.

item.title: chaos-mesh-action: Integrate Chaos Engineering into Your CI
item.description: Chaos Mesh is a cloud-native chaos testing platform that orchestrates chaos in Kubernetes environments. This article shares how to use chaos-mesh-action, a GitHub action to integrate Chaos Mesh into the CI process.

item.title: Chaos Mesh 1.0: Chaos Engineering on Kubernetes Made Easier
item.description: Today, we are proud to announce the general availability of Chaos Mesh® 1.0, following its entry into CNCF as a sandbox project in July, 2020. After 10 months of effort within the open-source community, Chaos Mesh is now ready in terms of functionality, scalability, and ease of use. Here are some highlights.

item.title: TiDB Operator: Your TiDB Operations Expert in Kubernetes
item.description: This post analyzes the pros and cons of running databases in Kubernetes. It also introduces TiDB Operator, a tool for managing TiDB clusters in Kubernetes, and describes how large companies are using it in their production environments as well as their best practices.

item.title: A Scale-Out Database Powers China's Letgo with Reduced Maintenance Costs
item.description: Zhuan Zhuan embraced TiDB 4.0's new features with great results. It's a truly HTAP database with one-minute deployment, visual troubleshooting, and reduced maintenance costs.

item.title: ZaloPay: Using a Scale-Out MySQL Alternative to Serve Millions of Users
item.description: A DevOps engineer in ZaloPay, Vietnam's most popular mobile payment application, shared why his team chose TiDB as ZaloPay's merchant platform core database. He talked about their pain points, how they use TiDB, and what he likes about it the most.

item.title: How We Build an HTAP Database That Simplifies Your Data Platform
item.description: This post talks about why HTAP matters in a database platform, how TiDB implements HTAP, and how you can apply TiDB in different scenarios.

item.title: Why We Chose an HTAP Database over MySQL for Horizontal Scaling and Complex Queries
item.description: After trying out different database solutions, BIGO chose TiDB. In this post, a BIGO DBA talks about TiDB 4.0's new features, how they benefit BIGO's business, and BIGO's plan to use TiDB 4.0 even more in the future.

item.title: Announcing HTAP support in TiDB Cloud
item.description: Today, we're glad to announce that TiDB Cloud, our fully managed database service powered by TiDB, now supports Hybrid Transactional/Analytical Processing (HTAP) workloads.

item.title: How to Migrate Data from Amazon Aurora MySQL to TiDB Cloud
item.description: This post introduces how to smoothly migrate data from Amazon Aurora MySQL to TiDB Cloud using Dumpling and TiDB Lightning.

item.title: Celebrate TiKV Graduation within CNCF
item.description: The Cloud Native Computing Foundation (CNCF) today just announced that TiKV has become the twelfth project to graduate, joining other graduated projects such as Kubernetes, Jaeger, Harbor, etc.

item.title: PingCAPers Make Their Debut at VLDB
item.description: The 46th VLDB conference will be broadcast online from August 31st to September 4th. PingCAP is honored to attend this conference, and we will share two papers with you TiDB: A Raft-based HTAP Database and Interleaved Multi-Vectorizing.

item.title: PingCAP Successfully Completes SOC 2 Type 1 Examination for TiDB Cloud
item.description: PingCAP, provider of the cloud-native hybrid transactional/analytical processing (HTAP) TiDB database, successfully completes an SOC 2 Type 1 examination for TiDB Cloud.

item.title: Why We Chose a Distributed SQL Database to Complement MySQL
item.description: VIPKid chose TiDB to manage its high data volume, highly concurrent write application. Learn how TiDB excels in that scenario, along with multidimensional queries, data life cycle management, and real-time analytics.

item.title: TiDB Cloud: Managed SQL at Scale on AWS and GCP
item.description: This post introduces in detail the features of TiDB Cloud - the fully managed, horizontally scaling, cloud-native, distributed SQL database in the cloud.

item.title: Building an Automated Testing Framework Based on Chaos Mesh® and Argo
item.description: This article describes how we use TiPocket, an automated testing framework, to build a full Chaos Engineering testing loop for TiDB.

item.title: Announcing PD Transfer to TiKV Project
item.description: We decide to move the Placement Driver library entirely to TiKV org, happening at 11 AM, UTC+8, August 17, 2020.

item.title: What's New and Improved in TiDB Docs
item.description: Along with the rapid releases of TiDB products and projects, we also constantly update and improve our TiDB documentation. This post covers recent big changes, new content, and improvements in TiDB documentation.

item.title: Japan's Largest Mobile Payment Company Migrates from Aurora to a Scale-Out Database
item.description: As PayPay's business grew, their payment management database became a bottleneck. Learn why PayPay chose TiDB over Aurora to handle their most crucial data and how efficiently they migrated to TiDB.

item.title: TiDB 4.0: An Elastic, Real-Time HTAP Database Ready for the Cloud
item.description: At TiDB DevCon 2020, Max Liu, CEO at PingCAP, gave a keynote speech. He believes that today's database should be more flexible, more real-time, and easier to use, and TiDB, an elastic, cloud-native, real-time HTAP database, is exactly that kind of database.

item.title: Create a Scale-Out Hive Cluster with a Distributed, MySQL-Compatible Database
item.description: This post shows how to deploy a Hive cluster with TiDB to achieve horizontal scalability of Hive Metastore.

item.title: Heterogeneous Database Replication to TiDB
item.description: PingCAP is experienced in heterogeneous database replication. This post gives best practice tips for database migration to TiDB.

item.title: Announcing Chaos Mesh® as a CNCF Sandbox Project
item.description: We're thrilled to announce that Chaos Mesh®, our open-sourced Chaos Engineering platform for Kubernetes, is now officially accepted as a CNCF Sandbox project.

item.title: Horizontally Scaling the Hive Metastore Database by Migrating from MySQL to TiDB
item.description: This post shows how TiDB helps Zhihu eliminate their database bottleneck and horizontally scale their Hive Metastore database to meet the growing business needs.

item.title: How TiDB's HTAP Makes Truly Hybrid Workloads Possible
item.description: This post introduces the design details of the HTAP architecture of TiDB, including the real-time updatable columnar engine, the multi-Raft replication strategy, and smart selection.

item.title: Cluster Diagnostics: Troubleshoot Cluster Issues Using Only SQL Queries
item.description: TiDB 4.0 introduces cluster diagnostics, a built-in widget in TiDB Dashboard, which lets you diagnose cluster problems within a specified time range. You can summarize the diagnostic results and cluster-related load monitoring information in a diagnostic report.

item.title: A Few More Reasons Rust Compiles Slowly
item.description: This is the fourth episode of the Rust Compile Time series. It discusses some factors that cause Rust to build slow, including LLVM, compiler architecture, and linking.

item.title: Announcing TiDB as a Service, Fully-Managed TiDB Offering
item.description: TiDB Cloud Beta is released. It's the easiest, most economical, and most resilient way to unlock the full power of TiDB in the cloud, allowing the users to deploy and run TiDB clusters with just a few clicks.

item.title: Rust's Huge Compilation Units
item.description: The third episode of the Rust Compile Time series discusses why Rust's compilation units are so big and how that affects compile times.

item.title: VLDB 2020: TiDB, A Raft-based HTAP Database
item.description: PingCAP will publish a research paper “TiDB: A Raft-based HTAP Database” in the August issue of the Proceedings of the VLDB Endowment.

item.title: TiDB 4.0 GA, Gearing You Up for an Unpredictable World with a Real-Time HTAP Database
item.description: TiDB 4.0 has reached general availability. It's an elastic, real-time Hybrid Transactional/Analytical Processing (HTAP) database, and, best of all, it's now ready for the cloud.

item.title: Generics and Compile-Time in Rust
item.description: This is the second episode of the Rust Compile Time series. Brian Anderson, one of Rust's original authors, talks about monomorphization, using the TiKV project as a case study.

item.title: How We Improved TPC-C Performance by 50% and TPC-H Performance by 100%
item.description: TiDB 4.0 release greatly outperforms TiDB 3.0. Our TPC-C benchmark improved by about 50% and our TPC-H benchmark improved by about 100%.

item.title: TiDB Dashboard: Easier Troubleshooting for Distributed Databases
item.description: TiDB 4.0 introduces TiDB Dashboard, which provides various built-in widgets in a graphical interface that let you easily diagnose, monitor, and manage your clusters in one place. Now you can troubleshoot TiDB clusters more easily.

item.title: Pessimistic Locking: Better MySQL Compatibility, Fewer Rollbacks Under High Load
item.description: With improvements in stability and functionality in TiDB 4.0, we finally remove the experimental label for pessimistic locking, making it a generally available feature. See how pessimistic locking behaves in TiDB.

item.title: TiCDC: Replication Latency in Milliseconds for 100+ TB Clusters
item.description: TiDB 4.0 introduces TiCDC, an open-source feature that replicates TiDB's incremental changes to downstream platforms. It shows only millisecond replication latency for 100+ TB clusters.

item.title: Large Transactions in TiDB
item.description: This post describes how we implemented support for large transactions in TiDB 4.0.

item.title: TiDB at ZaloPay Infrastructure & Lesson Learned
item.description: As VNG's business developed, their infrastructure became an obstacle to their growth. Then they chose TiDB as the core database for their ZaloPay app and used it to store their critical data. Now, VNG has 20+ TiDB nodes in their production environment.

item.title: SQL Plan Management: Never Worry About Slow Queries Again
item.description: This post introduces how SQL Plan Management helps the optimizer automatically select efficient execution plans to prevent performance regressions caused by unexpected plan changes.

item.title: Building, Running, and Benchmarking TiKV and TiDB
item.description: This post introduces how to build and run your own TiDB or TiKV, and how to run some benchmarks on those databases.

item.title: Get a TiDB Cluster Up in Only One Minute
item.description: TiUP is a component manager that streamlines installing and configuring a TiDB cluster into a few easy commands. It helps get your cluster up and running quickly with a minimal learning curve.

item.title: Key Visualizer: Observe Distributed Databases to Discover the Unknowns
item.description: Key Visualizer is a visual diagnostic tool that makes it easier to troubleshoot distributed SQL databases. Users can observe system health, quickly find hotspots in the cluster, and gain deep insights into applications.

item.title: Simulating Clock Skew in K8s Without Affecting Other Containers on the Node
item.description: As a cloud-native chaos engineering platform, Chaos Mesh supports TimeChaos, which simulates clock skew in containers or K8s for distributed systems to test system robustness, without affecting other containers on the node.

item.title: How to Back Up and Restore a 10-TB Cluster at 1+ GB/s
item.description: Backing up or restoring a large-scale distributed SQL database is a time-consuming task. Our upcoming TiDB 4.0 release will support Backup & Restore (BR), a distributed backup and restore tool, which lets you back up and restore data at 1+ GB/s for 10-TB data.

item.title: TiDB 4.0 Preview: An Easier-to-Use, Production-Ready HTAP Database
item.description: Get a preview of TiDB 4.0. Our landmark release has production-ready HTAP capabilities, continues to solve issues for large-scale, distributed SQL databases, and is easier to use than ever.

item.title: A Peek into the Future of Database: A Unified Infrastructure to Adapt Intelligently
item.description: Today is PingCAP's 5-year birthday. In this post, Ed Huang, PingCAP's CTO, discusses about what he thinks the future holds for databases. The future of the database is about unification, adaptiveness, and intelligence.

item.title: Quickly Find Rust Program Bottlenecks Online Using a Go Tool
item.description: It can be hard to find Rust programs’ performance bottlenecks online. By integrating pprof-rs in TiKV, we can use the Go tool pprof to visualize TiKV's profiling data. This helps analyze the program's performance online.

item.title: Run Your First Chaos Experiment in 10 Minutes
item.description: In this 10-minute tutorial, we will help you to quickly get started with Chaos Engineering and run your first chaos experiment with Chaos Mesh.

item.title: Choosing the Right Database for Your Applications
item.description: With so many databases on the market, choosing the right fit for your app is not an easy task. As a leading e-commerce platform in Southeast Asia and Taiwan, Shopee has an effective strategy for database selection. Learn from their experience.

item.title: TiDB Usability Challenge - Dare to Dream Bigger
item.description: TiDB Challenge Program is a series community program to bring TiDB to a new level in terms of stability, performance, and usability. With amazing improvements in performance in season 1 last year, we are now pleased to announce that season 2 is ready for you.

item.title: TiDB Celebrates 400 Contributors
item.description: The TiDB repository reaches the 400th contributor milestone. All our honors and achievements belong to the TiDB community, our beloved contributors, and distinguished committers.

item.title: Early Impressions of Go from a Rust Programmer
item.description: Nick Cameron is a long-time Rust programmer who has recently started using Go. In this post, he talks about his early impressions of Go. Read this post to learn more.

item.title: How We Reduced Multi-region Read Latency and Network Traffic by 50%
item.description: High read latency and network traffic are common issues for a multi-region architecture. At TiDB Hackathon 2019, a team won 2nd place by reducing multi-region read latency and network traffic by 50%. Read this post to learn how they did it.

item.title: Remote Work - Part 3
item.description: It's the third post in a series on remote work. In this post, Nick Cameron talks a bit about some of the practicalities, specifically around work and life balance.

item.title: Remote Work - Part 2
item.description: Nick Cameron has nearly ten-year experience of remote work. In this post, he discusses communication in remote work.

item.title: Remote Work - Part 1
item.description: Nick has been working remotely for nearly ten years. In this post, he introduces why you might benefit from remote work and some of the things that make remote work successful.

item.title: Doubling System Read Throughput with Only 26 Lines of Code
item.description: The Follower Read feature lets any follower replica in a Region serve a read request under the premise of strongly consistent reads. It reduces the load on the Raft leader and improves the read throughput of the TiDB cluster. Read this post to learn more.

item.title: The Rust Compilation Model Calamity
item.description: In this first episode of the Rust Compile time series, Brian Anderson, one of Rust's original authors, shares with you his researches and experiences with Rust compile times, using the TiKV project as a case study.

item.title: Chaos Mesh - Your Chaos Engineering Solution for System Resiliency on Kubernetes
item.description: Recently, PingCAP open-sourced Chaos Mesh, a Chaos Engineering platform that features all-around fault injection methods for complex Kubernetes systems. Find out how this testing tool can make your applications more reliable.

item.title: How TiKV Reads and Writes
item.description: This post details how TiKV, as a distributed database, stores the data contained in a write request and how it retrieves the corresponding data with consistency guaranteed.

item.title: AutoTiKV: TiKV Tuning Made Easy by Machine Learning
item.description: AutoTiKV is a machine-learning-based tuning tool that helps decrease tuning costs and make life easier for DBAs. This post shows AutoTiKV's design, its machine learning model, and the automatic tuning workflow.

item.title: Squashed Bugs, Served Hot and Fresh with Failure Rate Heatmaps
item.description: At TiDB Hackathon 2019, a team won the third prize by building a bot that helps quickly locate bugs in the code. Read this post to get more details.

item.title: How We Achieved 40 K QPS and 20+ Billion Rows of Data in a Single Scale-out Cluster
item.description: As the business developed, standalone MySQL couldn't meet JD Cloud & AI's OSS metadata storage requirements. This post introduces how TiKV empowered JD Cloud & AI to manage huge amounts of OSS metadata with a simple and horizontally scalable architecture.

item.title: NetEase Games: Why We Chose TiDB over Other MySQL-based and NewSQL Storage Solutions
item.description: As business boomed, NetEase Games met bottlenecks in database scalability and data isolation. This post introduces why they chose TiDB over other MySQL-based and NewSQL storage solutions to solve their pain points.

item.title: New Structure, New Roles - TiDB Community Upgrade!
item.description: PingCAP has upgraded and adjusted the TiDB community organization structure, with more community roles and community organizations introduced to better stimulate the vitality of the community and maintain a positive and healthy community environment.

item.title: 10x Performance Improvement for Expression Evaluation Made Possible by Vectorized Execution and the Community
item.description: We vectorized 360+ built-in functions along with the TiDB community. Vectorized execution has greatly improved the expression evaluation performance. Some functions even achieved 10x performance. Here is our vectorization story.

item.title: Building a Large-scale Distributed Storage System Based on Raft
item.description: This post introduces the PingCAP team's firsthand experience in designing a large-scale distributed storage system based on the Raft consensus algorithm.

item.title: How We Compiled a Golang Database in the Browser Using WebAssembly
item.description: We compiled a Golang database (TiDB) into an in-browser database using WebAssembly (Wasm). This post introduces why and how we built an in-browser database.

item.title: TiDB in the Browser: Running a Golang Database on WebAssembly
item.description: This post introduces how you can run TiDB directly in a web browser, how it is possible, and what the limitations are.

item.title: Delivering Real-time Analytics and True HTAP by Combining Columnstore and Rowstore
item.description: TiDB is an HTAP database that targets both OLTP and OLAP scenarios. TiFlash is its extended analytical engine. This post introduces how TiFlash fuels TiDB to become a true HTAP database that lets users perform real-time analytics.

item.title: INSERT INTO tidb.hackathon_2019 VALUES ("Hack", "Fun", "TiDB Ecosystem")
item.description: This post introduces the top 3 winners at TiDB Hackathon 2019 and the cozy and friendly environment of this meeting.

item.title: Safety First! Common Safety Pitfalls in Distributed Databases Found by Jepsen Tests
item.description: This post introduces why Jepsen is important to the distributed database industry, how it works, common issues found, how we use Jepsen with TiDB, and a short summary of all problems Jepsen has found.

item.title: How TSQ Becomes a Performance Bottleneck for TiKV in AWS ARM Environment
item.description: Explore into Linux kernel to find out how TSQ becomes a performance bottleneck for TiKV in an AWS ARM environment.

item.title: Lesson Learned from Queries over 1.3 Trillion Rows of Data Within Milliseconds of Response Time at Zhihu.com
item.description: As the business boomed and massive data in applications accrued each month, Zhihu faced severe challenges in scaling the backend system. This post introduces how Zhihu managed to keep milliseconds of query response time over a large amount of data and how TiDB, an open source MySQL-compatible HTAP database, empowered Zhihu to get real-time insights into data.

item.title: Porting TiDB to ARM64 for Greater Flexibility
item.description: This article describes how PingCAP compiled and benchmarked TiDB on the Amazon Web Services (AWS) ARM64 platform.

item.title: Migrating the TiKV Rust Client from Futures 0.1 to 0.3
item.description: This post introduces Nick's experience in migrating the TiKV Rust client from Futures 0.1 to 0.3.

item.title: TiDB Operator 1.0 GA: Database Cluster Deployment and Management Made Easy with Kubernetes
item.description: Deploying transactional databases like TiDB in Kubernetes for production has always been challenging. Now, with TiDB Operator 1.0, running TiDB database clusters has never been easier.

item.title: Why Benchmarking Distributed Databases Is So Hard
item.description: Benchmarks are hard to get right, and many articles touting benchmarks are actually benchmarketing, showcasing skewed outcomes to sell products. This post introduces some of the motivations for benchmarking and the common tools, and discusses a few things to keep in mind when benchmarking.

item.title: The KOST Stack: An Open-Source Cloud-Native Hybrid Database Stack
item.description: A new infrastructure pattern is emerging called the KOST stack (Kubernetes, Operator, Spark, TiDB). This blog post introduces each component of the KOST stack and cloud-native HTAP in the wild.

item.title: TiDB 3.0 Reaches GA, Delivers Stability at Scale and Performance Boost
item.description: TiDB 3.0 is released! This blog post introduces some highlights of TiDB 3.0, including major features focused on stability, significant performance improvements in Sysbench and TPC-C benchmarks, a newly introduced component, and important features and improvements.

item.title: Distributed Systems Training in Go and Rust
item.description: PingCAP has made a talent plan for training and/or evaluating students, new employees, and new contributors to TiDB and TiKV. This blog post gives a brief overview of training courses for this plan on writing distributed systems in Go and Rust.

item.title: Best Practices for Developing Applications with TiDB
item.description: This article shows how to efficiently develop high-quality applications with TiDB, an open-source NewSQL database that supports Hybrid Transactional and Analytical Processing (HTAP) workloads and can serve as a scale-out MySQL database without manual sharding.

item.title: TiDB Passes Jepsen Test for Snapshot Isolation and Single-Key Linearizability
item.description: TiDB's first official Jepsen Test report is published. This post introduces some additional context to the test results and PingCAP's thoughts on what's next.

item.title: Percona Live Austin -- Summary and Reflection
item.description: In this post, Kevin Xu shares the PingCAP team's experience and activities at Percona Live in Austin, including several technical sharing sessions and boosting friendship with people inside and outside PingCAP.

item.title: Tutorial: Use TiDB DM to Migrate and Replicate Data from MySQL, MariaDB & Amazon Aurora
item.description: Learn to migrate and replicate data from MySQL, MariaDB and Amazon Aurora using TiDB Data Migration.

item.title: Design and Implementation of Golang Failpoints
item.description: This post introduces design and implementation of Golang Failpoint.

item.title: TiDB Binlog Tutorial
item.description: Learn to deploy TiDB Binlog with a simple TiDB cluster.

item.title: PingCAP Open-Sources TiDB Binlog to Reduce Migration Cost
item.description: Our team at PingCAP is excited to announce that we are open-sourcing our own binlog implementation, TiDB Binlog. TiDB Binlog is a tool we've been developing in-house (until now) to collect binary log data from TiDB server and provide real-time data backup and replication.

item.title: Try to Fix Two Linux Kernel Bugs While Testing TiDB Operator in K8s
item.description: This post introduces how the EE team at PingCAP tackled two Linux kernel bugs while testing TiDB Operator in K8s. PingCAP engineers also hope the K8s community, RHEL and CentOS can help fix these bugs thoroughly in the near future.

item.title: PingCAPers at the First RustCon Asia!
item.description: PingCAP has been an active member in the Rust community and one of the first production users of Rust in building TiKV. As part of being a co-organizer for the first RustCon Asia, PingCAP also contributed several topics in both keynote sessions and workshops.

item.title: Titan: A RocksDB Plugin to Reduce Write Amplification
item.description: As a RocksDB plugin for key-value separation, inspired by WiscKey, Titan is available for preview in TiDB 3.0. This post introduces the design and implementation of Titan.

item.title: Powering the Xiaomi Mobile Lifestyle with TiDB
item.description: As sales of Xiaomi smartphones continue to climb and the MIUI user base continues to grow, the Database Administration team at Xiaomi was having an increasingly hard time managing their MySQL database infrastructure until they adopted TiDB, an open source distributed hybrid transactional and analytical processing database created and supported by PingCAP. Now they also have plans to migrate additional workloads to TiDB in the future.

item.title: Introduction to Analytics Queries for the MySQL DBA
item.description: This post introduces some simple use cases of analytics queries where a MySQL DBA can expand their repertoire and answer some basic business questions by writing SQL queries with window functions.

item.title: BookMyShow.com: More Uptime, 30% Less Operational Cost with TiDB
item.description: With TiDB, BookMyShow has experienced increased uptime and availability, since TiDB automatically partitions and distributes data across the cluster. Meanwhile, operational and maintenance cost has been reduced by 30%. No engineer needs to be fully dedicated to database operations anymore. This post will introduce why BookMyShow chose TiDB over Greenplum by illustrating how TiDB solved their pain points.

item.title: TiSpark: More Data Insights, Less ETL
item.description: The motivation behind building TiSpark was to enable real-time analytics on TiDB without the delay and challenges of ETL. Extract, transform, and load (ETL)–a process to extract data from operational databases, transform that data, then load it into a database designed to supporting analytics–has been one of the most complex, tedious, error-prone, and therefore disliked tasks for many data engineers. However, it was a necessary evil to make data useful, because there hasn't been good solutions on the market to render ETL obsolete–until now.

item.title: From Chaos to Order -- Tools and Techniques for Testing TiDB, A Distributed NewSQL Database
item.description: As an open source distributed NewSQL Hybrid Transactional/Analytical Processing (HTAP) database, TiDB contains the most important asset of our customers–their data. One of the fundamental and foremost requirements of our system is to be fault-tolerant. But how do you ensure fault tolerance in a distributed database? This article covers the top fault injection tools and techniques in Chaos Engineering, as well as how to execute Chaos practices in TiDB.

item.title: Blitzscaling the Largest Dockless Bikesharing Platform with TiDB's Help
item.description: Mobike has been using the TiDB database in the production environment since early 2017. Now they have deployed TiDB in multiple clusters with close to 100 nodes, handling dozens of TBs of data for different application scenarios. This post will provide a deep dive on why Mobike chose TiDB over MySQL and its sharding solutions by illustrating how TiDB solves their pain points.

item.title: How to do Performance Tuning on TiDB, A Distributed NewSQL Database
item.description: Doing performance tuning on distributed systems is no joking matter. It's much more complicated than on a single node server, and bottlenecks can pop up anywhere, from system resources in a single node or subcomponent, to cooperation between nodes, to even network bandwidth. Performance tuning is a practice that aims to find these bottlenecks and address them, in order to reveal more bottlenecks and address them as well, until the system reaches an optimal performance level. In this article, I will share some best practices on how to tune “write” operations in TiDB to achieve maximum performance.

item.title: Subquery Optimization in TiDB
item.description: Subquery optimization, especially rewriting the correlated subquery, is a very difficult part in SQL query optimization. To be compatible with MySQL, TiDB enables users to write subqueries anywhere they want. For those subqueries that are not correlated, which are also called uncorrelated subqueries, TiDB evaluates in advance; for those correlated subqueries, TiDB removes the correlations as much as possible. For example, TiDB can rewrite a correlated subquery to SemiJoin. This article is focused on introducing the correlated subquery optimization methods in TiDB.
